speaker: RONNIE
line: Help me! Somebody help me! Help! That guy's gonna to kill me! Help!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Look at that. Huh... Huh?

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, shi...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder--

speaker: MULDER
line: Don't. Don't even start with me. I know what I saw.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Skinner wants our report in one hour. What are you going to tell him?

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean what am I going to tell him? I'm going to tell him exactly what I saw. What are you going to tell him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'll tell him exactly what I saw.

speaker: MULDER
line: Now, how is that different? Look, Scully, I'm the one who may wind up going to prison here. I got to know if you're going to back me up or what.

speaker: SCULLY
line: First of all, if the family of Ronnie Strickland does indeed decide to sue the FBI for -- I think the figure is $446 million -- then you and I both will most certainly be co-defendants and second of all... I don't even have a second of all, Mulder. $446 million. I'm in this as deep as you are and I'm not even the one that overreacted. I didn't do the... with the thing.

speaker: MULDER
line: I did not overreact. Ronnie Strickland was a vampire.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where is your proof?

speaker: MULDER
line: You're my proof. You were there. OK, now you're scaring me. I wanna know exactly what you're gonna tell Skinner.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, you want our stories straight.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no, no, I didn't say that. I just want to hear it the way you saw it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't feel comfortable with that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Prison, Scully. Your cell mate's nickname is going to be Large Marge. She's going to read a lot of Gertrude Stein.

speaker: SCULLY
line: All right.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right, start at the beginning.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The very beginning? Fine. Yesterday morning... when I arrived at work, you were, uh... characteristically exuberant.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hope you brought your cowboy boots.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You want us to go to Dallas?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yee-haw! Actually, a town called Chaney, about 50 miles south of there, population 361... by all accounts, very rustic and charming, but as of late, ground zero the locus for a series of mysterious nocturnal exsanguinations.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Exsanguinations? Of whom?

speaker: MULDER
line: How does that grab ya?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is it a...?

speaker: MULDER
line: Dead cow! Exactly. Specifically, a dead 900-pound Holstein. Its body drained of blood as was this one,... this one, this one, this one, and so on. Six, all in all --approximately one a week over the past six weeks.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is there any sign of --?

speaker: MULDER
line: Two small puncture wounds on the neck?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I wasn't asking that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Too bad. We got 'em. Check it out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, these may be syringe marks. Their placement meant to emulate fangs. Such ritualistic blood-letting points towards cultists of some sort, in which case... What?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, that's probably it, satanic cultists. Come on, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're not gonna tell me you think it's that Mexican goat sucker thing.

speaker: MULDER
line: El Chupacabra? No, they got four fangs, not two, and they suck goats, hence the name.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, instead, this would be...

speaker: MULDER
line: Classic vampirism.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Of a bunch of cows.

speaker: MULDER
line: And one dead human last night - a vacationer from New Jersey. Come on, we got to go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why the hell didn't you tell me that from the beginning?

speaker: MULDER
line: Lock the door on your way out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The town of Chaney is too small to maintain a morgue facility. As such, we made our way to the Peaceful Slumbers funeral home in order to examine the body of one Mr. Dwight Funt, recently deceased. It was there that we were met by a representative of local law enforcement, Sheriff...

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Lucius Hartwell. You the FBI agents?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes. I'm... Agents Mulder and... uh... Scully. What do you say, we go take a look at your victim.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yeah, by all means. After you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on, Scully, get those little legs moving. Come on.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Boy.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Here we go.

speaker: MULDER
line: Nice threads.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No exam has been done?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: No, ma'am. He's just like we found him in the motel room. Once I heard you folks were interested I figured we'd best leave it up to the experts.

speaker: MULDER
line: Your satanic cultists have some sharp little teeth.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: What satanic cultists?

speaker: MULDER
line: Go ahead, tell him your, uh, "theory."

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, my theory has evolved. Basically, I think that we're looking for someone who has seen one too many Bela Lugosi movies. He believes he is a vampire, therefore...

speaker: HARTWELL
line: They act like one. Yeah. Yeah. That makes a whole lot of sense. I think she's right.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about the fang marks?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, someone so obsessed might well file down their incisors. I think that a moulage casting should help us make an identification.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Moulage casting, that's a good idea. Now... now, isn't there some kind of disease that makes a person think that they're a vampire?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, there is a psychological fixation called hematodipsia which causes the sufferer to gain erotic satisfaction from consuming human blood.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Erotic. Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mmm. There are also genetic afflictions which cause a heightened sensitivity to light, uh, to garlic -- porphyria, xeroderma pigmentosum.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: You really know your stuff, Dana.

speaker: MULDER
line: Dana?! He never even knew your first name.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're gonna interrupt me or what?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. Go ahead..... Dana.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Anyway... that's when you had your big... breakthrough... whatever.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Agent Scully, you really know your stuff.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sheriff, you say this man is exactly as you found him?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yes, sir, to the letter.

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you noticed that this man's shoes are untied?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yeah, they sure are.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, what's your point?

speaker: MULDER
line: This means something. Sheriff, do you have an old cemetery in town off the beaten path, the creepier the better?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Uh, yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Take me there now.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, we're going to need a complete autopsy on this man, the sooner the better.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. What am I even looking for?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He does that.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on, Sheriff Hartwell.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Ma'am. LATER

speaker: SCULLY
line: 4:54 PM, begin autopsy on white male, age 60, who is arguably having a worse time in Texas than I am... although not by much. I'll begin with the "y" incision. Yee-haw. LATER

speaker: SCULLY
line: Heart weighs 370 grams, tissue appears healthy. Left lung weighs 345 grams, tissue appears healthy. Large intestine... 890 grams, yada yada yada. LATER

speaker: SCULLY
line: Stomach contents show last meal close to the time of death, consisting of... pizza. Topped with pepperoni, green peppers, mushrooms... mushrooms... That sounds really good.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Having completed the autopsy I checked into the Davey Crockett Motor Court.

speaker: MULDER
line: The name of it was actually the Sam Houston Motor Lodge.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Chloral hydrate.

speaker: MULDER
line: What?

speaker: SCULLY
line: What the hell happened to you?

speaker: MULDER
line: Nothing. Chloral hydrate?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. That thing that you didn't know that you were looking for -- chloral hydrate -- more colorfully known as knockout drops. I found it in abundance when I sent the tox screen in on our murder victim. Now, seriously, Mulder. What happened to you?

speaker: MULDER
line: Nothing. Who slipped him the mickey?

speaker: SCULLY
line: My... "theory?" Your vampire. He found it necessary to dope poor Mr. Funt to the gills before he was able to extract his blood... Probably did it to the cows, too.

speaker: MULDER
line: What kind of vampire would do that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Exactly.

speaker: MULDER
line: We got another dead tourist. You got to do another autopsy.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Tonight? I just put money in the magic fingers!

speaker: MULDER
line: I won't let it go to waste.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This one's my room, Mulder. Don't get mud everywhere.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. Okay. OUTSIDE

speaker: RONNIE
line: Excuse me, ma'am, did you order a pizza?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. The guy in there'll pay for it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Foregoing both dinner and sleep, I was soon back at the funeral home examining one Mr. Paul Lombardo from Naples... Florida. Heart... lung... large intestine. As with the previous victim, it appears that the subject was most likely incapacitated with chloral hydrate, and then exsanguinated. The drug was either injected or ingested. I'm not sure which. Scully. Hello? Hello? Where was I? Stomach contents. Stomach contents include... pizza... Chloral hydrate's in the pizza. The pizza guy. Mulder!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, luckily, I'd gotten there in time. I mean, though you were drugged, you were... more or less unharmed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder? Are you okay?

speaker: MULDER
line: Who's the black private dick who's a sex machine with all the chicks? Shaft! Can you dig it? They say this cat Shaft is a bad mother... Shut your mouth! Talkin' 'bout Shaft.

speaker: MULDER
line: I did not!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Long story short. Though my first four shots obviously missed Ronnie Strickland entirely, with my fifth I was able to shoot out a tire on his car, forcing him to escape on foot. I left you behind and I entered the woods in pursuit. I assumed that you were incapacitated. Then I heard screaming. When I arrived in the clearing, I found that you had caught up with him first and had... over reacted. And that his vampire teeth were fake.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's what you're going to tell Skinner?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I'm going to argue that we caught a killer -- an utterly non-supernatural killer, but a killer nonetheless. And that your zeal to catch up with him was augmented by the chloral hydrate you were given.

speaker: MULDER
line: You are afraid to tell the truth.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's not the way it happened at all. I mean, what are you afraid of? That if you tell it the way it really happened, that you'll look like an idiot, like me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder? Why don't you tell me the way you think it happened? Starting at the beginning.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're damn right. Yesterday morning began like any other morning. You arrived at the office characteristically less than exuberant.

speaker: MULDER
line: I hope you brought your cowboy boots.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why are we going to Dallas?

speaker: MULDER
line: Actually, it's a little town just south of there called Chaney, Texas. They've had some incidents down there recently, which I think you'll agree, are pretty unusual.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Like what?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I-I brought some slides with which to better illustrate. Here we go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's a dead cow.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's actually six dead cows. And here's the really interesting thing...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why am I looking at six dead cows?

speaker: MULDER
line: Um, well, because of the manner in which they died. All six were mysteriously exsanguinated.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And?

speaker: MULDER
line: And two little puncture marks right here on the neck. Look, I got a slide of that. And, um, one dead human victim. Last night -- a vacationer from New Jersey. His body completely drained of blood and two little puncture wounds on his neck. Okay, look, Scully I-I don't want to jump to any hasty conclusions, but on the strength of the evidence that we have here, I think that what we *may* be looking at is what *appears* to be a series of vampire or *vampire-like* acts.

speaker: SCULLY
line: On what do you base that?!

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh... well, on the corpses drained of blood and the fang marks on the neck. But, as always, I'm very eager to hear your opinion.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it's obviously not a vampire.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, why not?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Because they don't exist?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well... that's... one opinion, and I respect that. Nonetheless, I'm thinking a murder has been committed here and we can go down there and help bring a killer to justice in whatever form -- mortal or... immortal he may take.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's not that Mexican goat sucker, either.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Upon arriving at the funeral home I made an interesting observation. One which you apparently didn't hear.

speaker: MULDER TALKING TO MORTICIAN
line: That's a whole lot of caskets.

speaker: MORTICIAN
line: Largest in-stock selection in the state.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why would a town with a population of only 361 need that?

speaker: MORTICIAN
line: Repeat business. Mortician humor. Excuse me.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Apparently your mind was somewhere else.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hoo, boy.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Y'all must be the gov'ment people. I'm Lucien Hartwell.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He had big buck teeth?

speaker: MULDER
line: He had a slight over bite.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, he didn't. And that's significant? How?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm just trying to be thorough. So, anyway, then we went to take a look at the body.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Here we go.

speaker: MULDER
line: No exam has been done?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: No, sir. This is just like we found him in the motel room as is.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No exam has been done?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Uh... No, ma'am. Once I heard y'all was interested I figured we'd best leave it to the experts. Now, uh... that can't be what it looks like, right?

speaker: MULDER
line: That depends on what you think it looks like, Sheriff Hartwell. Vampires have always been with us, in ancient myths and stories passed down from early man. From the Babylonian Ekimu to the Chinese Kuang-Shi to Motetz Dam of the Hebrews, the Mormo of ancient Greece and Rome to the more familiar Nosferatu of Transylvania.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Mormo. Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: In short, Sheriff, no. This can't be what it looks like. I think what we're dealing with here is simply a case of some lunatic. Who, uh, has watched too many Bela Lugosi movies. He wishes that he could transfigure himself into a creature of the night.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yeah. Okay. Uh... what she said, that's what I'm thinking, and, uh... Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Still, that leaves us in something of a quandary because there are as many different kinds of vampires as there are cultures that fear them. Some don't even subsist on blood. The Bulgarian Ubour, for example, eats only manure.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: To the Serbs, a prime indicator of vampirism is red hair. Some vampires are thought to be eternal. Others are thought to have a life span of only 40 days. Sunlight kills certain vampires while others come and go as they please, day or night. .

speaker: SCULLY
line: If there's a point, Mulder, please feel free to come to it.

speaker: MULDER
line: My point is that we don't know exactly what we're looking for. What kind of vampire, or if you prefer, what kind of vampire this killer wishes himself to be.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Now, why is it so important that his shoes were untied?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm getting to it. CEMETERY - DAY

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: So, while you stayed behind to do the autopsy, the Sheriff drove me to the town cemetery.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Agent Mulder, you mind me asking you why we're out here?

speaker: MULDER
line: Historically, cemeteries were thought to be a haven for vampires as are castles, catacombs and swamps, but unfortunately, you don't have any of those.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: We used to have swamps only the EPA made us take to calling them wetlands.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. So, we're out here looking for any signs of vampiric activity.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Which would be like, uh...?

speaker: MULDER
line: Broken or shifted tombstones. The absence of birds singing.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: There you go. Cuz I ain't hearing any birds singing. Right? Course, it's winter, and we ain't got no birds. Is there anything else?

speaker: MULDER
line: A faint groaning coming from under the earth. The sound of manducation -- of the creature eating its own death shroud.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Nope. No manuh... ma-ma...

speaker: MULDER
line: Manducation.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Manducation. No.

speaker: MULDER
line: Now, Sheriff, I know my methods may seem a little odd to you, but..

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Hey, look, y'all work for the federal guv'mint and that's all I need to know. I mean, CIA, Secret Service -- y'all run the show, so --

speaker: MULDER
line: It's just that my gut instinct tells me that the killer will visit this place. That it may well hold some fascination -- some kind of siren call for him, you know.

speaker: RONNIE
line: Howdy, Sheriff.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Oh, hey, Ronnie. How's it going?

speaker: RONNIE
line: Can't complain.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Well, all right, then.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe after nightfall, Sheriff, but he'll come. Oh, he'll come.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: So, we staked out the cemetery.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, shoelaces?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hmm?

speaker: SCULLY
line: On the corpse. You were going to tell me what was meaningful about finding untied shoelaces.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm getting to it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sunflower seed? Sorry.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: No, thanks. Do you mind... do you mind me asking you what you were...

speaker: MULDER
line: Historically, certain types of seeds were thought to fascinate vampires. Chiefly oats and millet, but you make do with what you have. Remember when I said before that we didn't know what type of vampire we were looking for?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, oddly enough, there seems to be one obscure fact which in all the stories told by the different cultures is exactly the same, and that's that vampires are really, really obsessive-compulsive. Yeah, you toss a handful of seeds at one, no matter what he's doing he's got to stop and pick it up. If he sees a knotted rope, he's got to untie it. It's in his nature. In fact, that's why I'm guessing that our victim's shoelaces were untied.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yeah, obsessive... Like Rain Man. It's like when that old boy dropped them matchsticks, he had to pick them all up. Same thing, right?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, he didn't actually pick them up. He counted them.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Oh, yeah. 247. Right off the top of your head.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, if he had picked them up he would have been a vampire.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yeah. I'll tell you what. I know I'm in law enforcement, but I'd like to take him to Vegas myself. Am I right?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that would be illegal, right?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: He's like a little calculator.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Excuse me. Hey, Charlene, what's up?

speaker: CHARLENE
line: I just got a call from the RV park. They got something of a situation there. Sounds like you might wanna have a look.

speaker: RONNIE
line: Hey, again, sheriff.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Hey, again, Ronnie.

speaker: RONNIE
line: I guess you got yourselves a runaway, uh?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Well, yeah, Ronnie, I guess we do. What do ya think? We ought to shoot the tires out?

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Anyway, skipping ahead...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why skip ahead? What happened then? Mulder? You shot out the tires, and what then?

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Here's something you may not know: Shooting out the tires on a runaway RV is a lot harder than it looks. I then tried a different approach. Help!

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Come on, bird dog it! Attaway!

speaker: MULDER
line: Help!

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Ow. How you doin' there?

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Finally, we prevailed.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: That's the same as the others.

speaker: MULDER
line: Right down to the shoes.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: We interviewed everyone present. No one had seen anything.

speaker: MULDER'S VOICE OVER
line: Tired, frustrated and lacking a solid lead, I just wanted to get cleaned up. I had the sheriff drop me at the motel, which is where I ran into you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What do you mean you want me to do another autopsy?! And why do I have to do it right now?! I just spent hours on my feet doing an autopsy, all for you. I do it all and all that was, was a half a cream cheese bagel, and it wasn't even real cream cheese, it was light cream cheese. And now you want me to run off and do another autopsy? What the hell happened to you?

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Finally... you left.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't you touch that bed. LATER

speaker: RONNIE
line: Hello? Hello? Ah, hey, again. The lady outside, she said that, um, you'd pay for this.

speaker: MULDER
line: She ordered a pizza from you? Excellent. How much?

speaker: MULDER
line: Let me get my wallet. How much?

speaker: MULDER
line: Okay, there's $13.

speaker: RONNIE
line: Okay, then. Enjoy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ah, Scully. LATER

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: So, I ate your dinner. And that's when I saw it. But by then it was too late.... Creep.

speaker: RONNIE
line: Oh, man! What'd you have to go and do that for? You are in big trouble.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Then I was out cold. I don't know for how long, but when I finally came to...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're saying that I actually hit him two times?

speaker: MULDER
line: Square in the chest. No effect.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And then he sort of flew at me like a flying squirrel?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I don't think I'll use the phrase "flying squirrel" when I talk to Skinner, but... yeah, that's what happened.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: You checked on me, then left to pursue Ronnie Strickland into the woods. Once I recovered I knew what I had to do.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: I caught sight of him, chased him over hill and dale, and in the end...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it's not just me. Nobody in their right mind will ever believe that story.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, they'll have to, once they examine Ronnie Strickland's body.

speaker: CORONER
line: Case 0026198, Ronald Lavelle Strickland. Probable cause of death... Gee, that's a tough one.

speaker: KIMBERLY
line: Assistant Director Skinner's office. Oh, I'm sorry, he's about to go into a meeting. Yes, it may last several hours. You're welcome.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, please just keep reminding him you were drugged.

speaker: MULDER
line: Would you stop that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It wouldn't hurt.

speaker: MULDER
line: Stop it.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Scully, Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: I was drugged!

speaker: SKINNER
line: I want you back in Texas. Ronnie Strickland's body has disappeared from the morgue. Apparently in conjunction with this, a coroner's been attacked... his throat was... bitten.

speaker: MULDER
line: The coroner's dead?

speaker: SKINNER
line: No, his... throat was bitten. It was sort of... gnawed on. Daylight's burning, agents.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But... he was dead.

speaker: MULDER
line: I noticed that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: With a stake through his heart.

speaker: MULDER
line: I noticed that, too.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So we should find Ronnie out here because...?

speaker: MULDER
line: Because tradition states that a vampire needs to sleep in his native soil.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But Mulder, he had fake fangs. Why would a real vampire need fake fangs? I mean, for the sake of argument.

speaker: MULDER
line: Fangs are very rarely mentioned in the folklore. Real vampires aren't actually thought to have them. It's more an invention of Bram Stoker's. I think maybe you were right before when you said that this is just a guy who's watched too many Dracula movies. He just happens to be a real vampire.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, so where the hell is he?

speaker: MULDER
line: What about his family -- the ones who are going to sue us for 446 million?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, an aunt and an uncle. Their mail comes general delivery to a local post office.

speaker: MULDER
line: No home address? That's the sheriff.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sheriff Hartwell.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Evening, agents. I heard y'all were back in town. Thought I might be of some assistance.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, actually you can. You can stay behind here with Agent Scully and keep an eye on things while I check something out. Don't say I never did nothing for ya.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where are you going?

speaker: MULDER
line: Where might you be living if your mail came general delivery around here?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: The RV park.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're good.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thanks.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: You're very welcome. So what do you think about vampires?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You mean aside from the fact that I don't believe in them?

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yeah, aside from that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well... they're supposed to be extremely charming. Seductive. No, I mean... even if they did really exist, who's to say they'd actually be like that? As Agent Mulder says, there are many different kinds of vampires.

speaker: HARTWELL
line: Yup. Sure are. I really need to apologize to you about Ronnie. He makes us all look bad. He's just not who we are anymore. I mean, we pay taxes, we're good neighbors. Old Ronnie, he just... he can't quite seem to grasp the concept of... low profile. But though he may be a moron, he is one of our own.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hello? Sleeping late. Ronnie Strickland... you have the right to remain silent. Anything you say can and will be used against you in a court of law. Come on, cut it out, Ronnie. Oh damn... Back! Ahh! No!! Aaaaahh!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, what happened?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I came to in the cemetery. That's all I know.

speaker: MULDER
line: They pulled up stakes.

speaker: SKINNER
line: So, that's it? They simply disappeared without a trace. And that's exactly the way it happened from start to finish?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I can neither confirm nor deny agent Mulder's version of events which occurred outside my presence.

speaker: MULDER
line: And I can neither confirm nor deny agent Scully's version of events, but, um...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Anyway... I was drugged.

speaker: MULDER
line: That is... essentially, exactly the way it happened.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Essentially.

speaker: MULDER VOICE OVER
line: Except for the part about the buck teeth.
